snippet.textDisplay:
I just picked up a 2011 M3 e92 with 29,500 miles from a dealer. DIY oil
change ($110) parts, new front tires ($430) installed, muffler mod
($350) and one of the HID angle eyes went out and replaced them with
standard H8 bulbs ($50). That's within the first 2 weeks of owning the
car. There is an annoying intermittent rattle noise somewhere above the
muffler area or possibly inside the muffler. Will be spending about
$1,500 to $2k on a new muffler, I just don't know which one to get.
Also, I have been visiting the gas stations a lot lately... I still love
this car.
snippet.textOriginal:
I just picked up a 2011 M3 e92 with 29,500 miles from a dealer. DIY oil 
change ($110) parts, new front tires ($430) installed, muffler mod 
($350) and one of the HID angle eyes went out and replaced them with 
standard H8 bulbs ($50). That's within the first 2 weeks of owning the 
car. There is an annoying intermittent rattle noise somewhere above the 
muffler area or possibly inside the muffler. Will be spending about 
$1,500 to $2k on a new muffler, I just don't know which one to get. 
Also, I have been visiting the gas stations a lot lately... I still love
 this car.

snippet.textDisplay: The "cold/hot" slider in the aircon is NOT a override switch. The system actually DOES respect the digital temperature control. The reason you have the slider is to define the temperature intensity coming off the main air vents. If it's a really hot day and you set the aircon to a low temp, the air coming off the vents might be too cold; some people might think that extremely cold air feels uncomfortable (specially due to the thermal shock), so you can adjust the slider closer to the "hot" (red) position. That will decrease the cold intensity coming off of the main vents, the system still respect the temperature you set in the dials, except that instead of blowing extremely cold air right into your face, it will instead divert the colder air to the other air vents (like the ones in the feet and the windshield) and the air coming off the main vents will be a little hotter. The same logic applies when using hot air on cold days. I personally think that having hot air blowing in my face feels extremely uncomfortable (even on cold days), but I don't like feeling cold in general. With BMW's system you can achieve having a generaly cool and pleasant air coming off the main vents (leaving the slider in the blue position) and still have the air heat the interior of the car (through the other vents). This way you can heat the interior of the car without feeling uncomfortable.
snippet.textOriginal: The "cold/hot" slider in the aircon is NOT a override switch. The system actually DOES respect the digital temperature control. The reason you have the slider is to define the temperature intensity coming off the main air vents. If it's a really hot day and you set the aircon to a low temp, the air coming off the vents might be too cold; some people might think that extremely cold air feels uncomfortable (specially due to the thermal shock), so you can adjust the slider closer to the "hot" (red) position. That will decrease the cold intensity coming off of the main vents, the system still respect the temperature you set in the dials, except that instead of blowing extremely cold air right into your face, it will instead divert the colder air to the other air vents (like the ones in the feet and the windshield) and the air coming off the main vents will be a little hotter. The same logic applies when using hot air on cold days. I personally think that having hot air blowing in my face feels extremely uncomfortable (even on cold days), but I don't like feeling cold in general. With BMW's system you can achieve having a generaly cool and pleasant air coming off the main vents (leaving the slider in the blue position) and still have the air heat the interior of the car (through the other vents). This way you can heat the interior of the car without feeling uncomfortable.

snippet.textDisplay: The hot/cold dial on the dash is so you can blow cool air on your face with the heat on for the rest of the vents. It's very useful if you are getting tired or want fresh air but don't want hot air drying out your eyes. This should definitely be a quirk or feature that doug understands.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yay Doug reviews a car I’ve actually owned! And one I had extensively researched before purchasing, a few things to note:

-I was surprised at Doug’s non-explanation of the Power button. It’s for the sensitivity of the throttle pedal. Its doesnt actually effect engine power at all, just makes the throttle more sensitive and makes the throttle map’s 100% WOT at say only 3/4 of the pedal travel compared to putting the pedal all the way with it in Normal. It can also be configured for your M Mode and pressing the M button on the wheel will activate it along with your other settings (dampers, servotronic steering, DCS MDM)

-Surprised Doug didnt mention the carbon leather trim. It’s a desirable option for buyers. Cloth seats are very rare too, its not part of some ‘enthusiast’ package like Doug mentioned, but most of these cars just came with the Novillo leather (mine had red).

-You can get the adjustable dampers outside of the Competition package, it was part of the tech package and even available al carte in the early pre LCI years iirc. The only difference with the Competition pkge ones was the Sport setting was retuned and now was dynamic like the Comfort and Normal settings.

-Don’t think that’s a rear armrest Doug. That piece pops out to allow the ski pass through (car has cold weather package), the little panel behind it is a door that opens into the trunk.

-Doug kept mentioning the V8 but didnt mention its crazy redline of 8,250 rpms! How do you not mention that! This small V8 is a revver and not torquey, I’m glad he did mention its characteristic of being high revving and not having grunt down low though. Also surprised he didn’t point out the warmup gauge around the tachometer that slowly reduces from red to yellow into the redline when you cold start the car as a quirk!

-He mentions the steering, it feels great cause its hydraulic. Last M car to have it, the M3/4 after this one have electric steering.

-This particular car also has the enhanced premium audio option, you can tell from the silver rings around the speakers (compared to black on the base audio)

-In case anyone cares, mine was a 2011 Space Grey Competition Package (ZCP) with 6MT :)
snippet.textOriginal:
Yay Doug reviews a car I’ve actually owned! And one I had extensively researched before purchasing, a few things to note:

-I was surprised at Doug’s non-explanation of the Power button. It’s for the sensitivity of the throttle pedal. Its doesnt actually effect engine power at all, just makes the throttle more sensitive and makes the throttle map’s 100% WOT at say only 3/4 of the pedal travel compared to putting the pedal all the way with it in Normal. It can also be configured for your M Mode and pressing the M button on the wheel will activate it along with your other settings (dampers, servotronic steering, DCS MDM)

-Surprised Doug didnt mention the carbon leather trim. It’s a desirable option for buyers. Cloth seats are very rare too, its not part of some ‘enthusiast’ package like Doug mentioned, but most of these cars just came with the Novillo leather (mine had red).

-You can get the adjustable dampers outside of the Competition package, it was part of the tech package and even available al carte in the early pre LCI years iirc. The only difference with the Competition pkge ones was the Sport setting was retuned and now was dynamic like the Comfort and Normal settings.

-Don’t think that’s a rear armrest Doug. That piece pops out to allow the ski pass through (car has cold weather package), the little panel behind it is a door that opens into the trunk.

-Doug kept mentioning the V8 but didnt mention its crazy redline of 8,250 rpms! How do you not mention that! This small V8 is a revver and not torquey, I’m glad he did mention its characteristic of being high revving and not having grunt down low though. Also surprised he didn’t point out the warmup gauge around the tachometer that slowly reduces from red to yellow into the redline when you cold start the car as a quirk!

-He mentions the steering, it feels great cause its hydraulic. Last M car to have it, the M3/4 after this one have electric steering.

-This particular car also has the enhanced premium audio option, you can tell from the silver rings around the speakers (compared to black on the base audio)

-In case anyone cares, mine was a 2011 Space Grey Competition Package (ZCP) with 6MT :)

snippet.textDisplay: The "up arrow" on the key fob probably  harks back to the old way of determining if the car door was locked by looking at the little post through the window.  When it was "up"/long the door was unlocked and when it was "down"/short the car door was locked.

snippet.textDisplay: Decent review.  While the "gong" is not particularly interesting it is useful.  It's actually kind of a catch all warning chime in BMWs.  Beyond the "welcome" sound it covers most of the warnings that the car will give you...exceed the "speed warning" limit that you set for yourself, tire pressure low, outside temperature 37 degrees or lower, low on oil, car going into "limp mode", low on fuel..all are indicated by this gong along with a few other things.  Small thing but just sharing a little info about that particular item.
snippet.textOriginal: Decent review.  While the "gong" is not particularly interesting it is useful.  It's actually kind of a catch all warning chime in BMWs.  Beyond the "welcome" sound it covers most of the warnings that the car will give you...exceed the "speed warning" limit that you set for yourself, tire pressure low, outside temperature 37 degrees or lower, low on oil, car going into "limp mode", low on fuel..all are indicated by this gong along with a few other things.  Small thing but just sharing a little info about that particular item.

snippet.textDisplay:
The turnsignal stock has two clicks per direction. One for continuous blinking and one for a sequence of 3. To turn the continuous turnsignal off, you gotta press the turn signal stock only to one click. It’s actually pretty easy and nice to use imo, i like it.

The Center console has a pretty quirky feature. You can move the drivers armrest forward individually for more armrest.
snippet.textOriginal:
The turnsignal stock has two clicks per direction. One for continuous blinking and one for a sequence of 3. To turn the continuous turnsignal off, you gotta press the turn signal stock only to one click. It’s actually pretty easy and nice to use imo, i like it.

The Center console has a pretty quirky feature. You can move the drivers armrest forward individually for more armrest.

snippet.textDisplay: What he's talking about with those turn signals ? This was since late 90's and is still in all bmw, and most manufacturers are copying it ... unless murcins got the "dumb spec" implemented just for them. Also the arm rest parts slide back independently ... is he high while reviewing it ? Power button only changes the throttle mapping curve, traction control is not dissabled after a short press - only a "dynamic traction control" - you need to hold down for 2 seconds to really disable traction and stability assist program. The warm / cold dial in the middle is for centre vent bias - if he crack it to the cold and sets dials to max temp climate controls would put more hot air over his feet and windscreen to compensate. Read the f** manual you toss pot. Competition package meant that rear arm rest did not had a hinge or built-in cup holders. And who gives a fuck about cup holders in m3 ?!?!?!!?!?!?!?!!?!?!?!?!?!!? Handling being 6 ????? hahahaha !!! and focus RS having a higher score HAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHA. Right, after this review I just look back at all his reviews and think how much misinformed they were ...

The warm / cold dial in the middle is for centre vent bias - if he crack it to the cold and sets dials to max temp climate controls would put more hot air over his feet and windscreen to compensate. snippet.textDisplay: Me not being a BMW driver, I still would say that this climate control feature is quite nice. My dad used to develop climate controls for BMW and he explained to me few days ago, that BMW did that, so that you could have the car warming up so you're not cold but have some coldish air flowing gently to your face so that you had a bit of fresh air, like a breeze. That was so that your head stayed cool. So i think it's quite a cool feature
snippet.textOriginal: Me not being a BMW driver, I still would say that this climate control feature is quite nice. My dad used to develop climate controls for BMW and he explained to me few days ago, that BMW did that, so that you could have the car warming up so you're not cold but have some coldish air flowing gently to your face so that you had a bit of fresh air, like a breeze. That was so that your head stayed cool. So i think it's quite a cool feature

snippet.textDisplay:
Lovely car, but so many things wrong with this review!

The arrow on the key points to the car when you point the key to the car, it means in! The power button doesn't turn power on/off, it sharpens up throttle & steering response & stiffens the dampers (on EDC cars). The hot/cold dial on the centre vents is brilliant because it allows you to have cold air to the face & still allow warm air to the feet & windscreen! Perfect! Is it that hard to work out?? (can't remember what else I wrote on my 1st attempt, stupid youtube autoplay! Which I've turned off multiple times before! grrr)

I don't believe the rod bearing issue shows up without any warning, so many drivers are just blindly oblivious to the sounds their car makes (or anything sometimes!!) that I think they just miss the sounds!!
Can't believe you didn't mention the throttle actuators issue! :p
snippet.textOriginal:
Lovely car, but so many things wrong with this review! 

The arrow on the key points to the car when you point the key to the car, it means in! The power button doesn't turn power on/off, it sharpens up throttle  & steering response & stiffens the dampers (on EDC cars). The hot/cold dial on the centre vents is brilliant  because it allows you to have cold air to the face & still allow warm air to the feet & windscreen! Perfect! Is it that hard to work out?? (can't remember what else I wrote on my 1st attempt, stupid youtube autoplay! Which I've turned off multiple times before! grrr) 

I don't believe the rod bearing issue shows up without any warning, so many drivers are just blindly oblivious to the sounds their car makes (or anything sometimes!!) that I think they just miss the sounds!! 
Can't believe you didn't mention the throttle actuators issue! :p

snippet.textDisplay: 9:45 ish - it doesn’t override the entire climate control setting, it controls the center vents only. It works really well and is extremely convenient for when, for example, your upper body is warmer than lower or vice versa. Also, it represents a 5 degree change (+-) from what’s on the screen. German climate control frequently sucks, so this helps you change the temp from the vents when your car is set to auto 70 but the air coming out feel too hot or cold.
snippet.textOriginal: 9:45 ish - it doesn’t override the entire climate control setting, it controls the center vents only. It works really well and is extremely convenient for when, for example, your upper body is warmer than lower or vice versa. Also, it represents a 5 degree change (+-) from what’s on the screen. German climate control frequently sucks, so this helps you change the temp from the vents when your car is set to auto 70 but the air coming out feel too hot or cold.

snippet.textDisplay:
Just a bit of correction.
I've the same car(not M3, 6cylinder 3Liter version). The armrest is split, cause you can move it forward, but if it would be the same lenght it would block the handbrake. So if you have your handbrake in the lowered position, you can have your armrest longer.
This generation of 3 series is my favorite, ive driven a lot of bmw's, but from the 3 series this was my favorite. The only new BMW this is similar to is the 2 series coupe, which I do honestly like, but I still prefer this one.

snippet.textDisplay: The dial in the middle allows you to change the temperature of the air hitting you in the face while the normal climate controls handle the overall temperature of the car. Some cars don't do this very well - such as every Lexus I've ever driven. They trickle cold air in your face once the cabin heats to the desired temperature. This causes you to keep bumping up the overall temperature to keep from having cold air blown on your face / hands. Some people like cold air on their face while driving to help keep them alert. BMW is one of the few cars that gets this right and lets you pick how you want this situation handled and it is, in fact, brilliant.
snippet.textOriginal: The dial in the middle allows you to change the temperature of the air hitting you in the face while the normal climate controls handle the overall temperature of the car. Some cars don't do this very well - such as every Lexus I've ever driven. They trickle cold air in your face once the cabin heats to the desired temperature. This causes you to keep bumping up the overall temperature to keep from having cold air blown on your face / hands. Some people like cold air on their face while driving to help keep them alert. BMW is one of the few cars that gets this right and lets you pick how you want this situation handled and it is, in fact, brilliant.

snippet.textDisplay:
The driver portion of the split armrests actually slides forward as far as the passenger side. This allows the e-brake to be pulled without hitting the driver side of the arm test. If you drive a S4 for the same era, the brake lever actually hits the arm rest when pulled.

The competition package not only lacks a sun roof but the roof is carbon for weight reduction and added head clearance.

Great review!
snippet.textOriginal:
The driver portion of the split armrests actually slides forward as far as the passenger side. This allows the e-brake to be pulled without hitting the driver side of the arm test. If you drive a S4 for the same era, the brake lever actually hits the arm rest when pulled. 

The competition package not only lacks a sun roof but the roof is carbon for weight reduction and added head clearance. 

Great review!

snippet.textDisplay: The bmw Z3 has a similar belt issue so they put a belt holder on the seat (which brake easily too).  The traction control has two way to do it too, one push then you get some traction control then push and hold it for 5-10 second or until the dash light up like a Christmas tree.  Almost 17 years with my Z3 and the turn signals was an option back then because... BMW lmao.   Fun video thank you for making it.

snippet.textDisplay: A bit heavy handed there Doug.  Being the only V8 M3 ever to be made, this version is special.  You failed to mention how Ferrari-like the engine is.  In fact it compares closely to the 355 and 360 V8's in terms of output and performance.   Pretty amazing for a 2 door German sedan.  I picked a 335is instead for its superior low end performance, and then Dinanized it.  I feel it is a more complete package than the E92 M3.  It actually out performs this stock V8 engine in every way except the red line.  Still, among the BMW fans, these V8 M3s are pretty special and collectible.
snippet.textOriginal: A bit heavy handed there Doug.  Being the only V8 M3 ever to be made, this version is special.  You failed to mention how Ferrari-like the engine is.  In fact it compares closely to the 355 and 360 V8's in terms of output and performance.   Pretty amazing for a 2 door German sedan.  I picked a 335is instead for its superior low end performance, and then Dinanized it.  I feel it is a more complete package than the E92 M3.  It actually out performs this stock V8 engine in every way except the red line.  Still, among the BMW fans, these V8 M3s are pretty special and collectible.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi Doug, few notes and questions on this one; 
A) I wonder if this car had the proximity entry (where you don't need to use the lock or unlock buttons on the fob , or a need to plug the key into the dash?
B) Does the windows go down when holding the 'up' button on the fob?
B) I bet the fabric seats help prevent your but from sliding on a leather seat in the corners.
C) The 'power' button, interesting but what's it do on this car? (On my 135 's' mode changes the throttle response, holds rpm and shift firmness).
D) Pretty sure the turn signal on my bmw will cancel if you gently depress the turn stock before it clicks ( not depressing all the way down)
E) Was there a 2 stage dsc traction control option (first stage disables traction control, second long press disables both stability and traction controls systems?
F) I wonder what more was part of the competition package?
G) I love how you were giving the other guy a little go at the lights there, lol

love the reviews
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi Doug, few notes and questions on this one; 
A) I wonder if this car had the proximity entry (where you don't need to use the lock or unlock buttons on the fob , or a need to plug the key into the dash?
B) Does the windows go down when holding the 'up' button on the fob?
B) I bet the fabric seats help prevent your but from sliding on a leather seat in the corners.
C) The 'power' button, interesting but what's it do on this car?  (On my 135 's' mode changes the throttle response, holds rpm and shift firmness).
D) Pretty sure the turn signal on my bmw will cancel if you gently depress the turn stock before it clicks ( not depressing all the way down)
E) Was there a 2 stage dsc traction control option (first stage disables traction control, second long press disables both stability and traction controls systems?
F) I wonder what more was part of the competition package?
G) I love how you were giving the other guy a little go at the lights there, lol

love the reviews

snippet.textOriginal: A BMW mechanic I spoke to a while back said only early E92 M3's had rod bearing problems. He mentioned that models from 2009 onward weren't affected, so this 2013 model shouldn't have any trouble!

snippet.textOriginal: https://youtu.be/68FJrq_mcXg pick me up in that m3

snippet.textDisplay: I owned a 2008 e93 M3 BMW for 10 years and traded it in last year.  When I got it, it was my dream car.  Driving it with the roof down and ripping the engine down a country road was the best way to experience this car.  I loved the way it looked and the way it drove.   But after time, all of its shortcomings really got to me and I traded it in.  While I didn't have rod bearing issues, I had to replace both actuators which were ridiculously overpriced.  Also the cheap leather lining that covers most of the interior was peeling off the steering wheel and the small holders in the car door.  The leather seats themselves were also starting to deteriorate. There were simply too many problems that I simply couldn't justify it being my daily driver any longer.

snippet.textDisplay: You missed the keyless entry on this car. It’s extremely quirky. The split armrest has a purpose. The one on the driver side slides forward so you can rest your arm on it if you are shorter and have the seat forward. It also goes back when you pull the parking brake. Which would be blocked when it is in the forward position. I bought a well seasoned one in Germany and it has been a joy but the maintenance is expensive. There really isn’t a thing as a cheap German car.
